item.title: Name of the work 2
item.description: When she reached the first hills of the Italic Mountains, she had a last view back on the skyline of her hometown Bookmarksgrove, the headline of Alphabet Village and the subline of her own road, the Line Lane.

item.title: Name of the work 3
item.description: Fifth abundantly made Give sixth hath. Cattle creature i be don’t them.

item.title: Item without image
item.description: Far far away, behind the word mountains, far from the countries Vokalia and Consonantia, there live the blind texts. A small river named Duden flows by their place and supplies it with the necessary regelialia. It is a paradisematic country, in which roasted parts of sentences fly into your mouth.

item.title: Converting from wide to long format & ANOVA in R
item.description: Introduction In this post, I will discuss about how to convert data from wide format to long format; how to create a 2D figure with information from 3 variables; and how to conduct ANOVA in 3 different ways. The data in today’s example was collected by our lab (led by Dr. Paul Minda) for the purpose of predicting category-learning on two types of categories (i.e.,RD: Rule-defined, and II: Information Integration). Columns from B to AY are all predictive variables.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.

item.title: Name of the work 1
item.description: Even the all-powerful Pointing has no control about the blind texts it is an almost unorthographic life. One day however a small line of blind text by the name of Lorem Ipsum decided to leave for the far World of Grammar.

item.title: About
item.description: This is a “hello world” example website for the blogdown package. The theme was forked from @jrutheiser/hugo-lithium-theme and modified by Yihui Xie.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.

item.title: CFA Model Modification in R lavaan
item.description: Introduction Confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) is the type of model that extracts common underlying variables from several observed variables and specifying the relationship between the observed and unobserved variables. In this post, I will run a CFA in R using the lavaan package, interpret the output, and make model modifications based on the results. Running a CFA in R library(knitr) library(lavaan) library(semPlot) library(data.table) I will use the Motivations for Alcohol Use Among Adolescents Questionnaire (Cooper, 1994) which consists of four subscales assessing motives for alcohol consumption: Social, Coping, Enhancement, and Conformity.

item.title: Exploratory Factor Analysis using R
item.description: Introduction In this post I will be using the 20-item CESD questionnaire as an example to conduct an exploratory factor analysis. The 20 items are shown in the figure below. Item 4, 8, 12, 16 are reverse-coded. Preparation Install Packages #install.packages("Hmisc") #install.packages('corrplot') #install.packages('psych') #install.packages('nFactors') #install.packages('GPArotation') #install.packages('sem') #install.packages("magrittr") #install.packages('kableExtra') Load libraries library(knitr) library(Hmisc) library(corrplot) library(psych) library(GPArotation) library(rmarkdown) library(sem) library(magrittr) library(kableExtra) Data Manipulation Subsetting data<-read.csv('CESD.csv') # exclude variables cesdx4,cesdx8,cesdx12, cesdx16 myvars <- names(data) %in% c("cesdx4", "cesdx8", "cesdx12", "cesdx16","gender") data <- data[!

item.title: Using VLookup to match Scantron grades with Gradebook list
item.description: Introduction As graduate Teaching Assitants, we are often assigned mundane tasks which require little to no intelletual involvement, and would be rather time consuming if no automatic method was applied. One of the tasks that is often assigned to us is posting grades for courses whose exam format is Multiple Choices. The way you want to avoid We would start with a .dat file containing the grades of the students that have taken part in the exam, along with their student numbers (but not their names).
